folder: Flushing Meadow Park & [New York World's Fair grounds.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (World's Fair Site) showing a set of 4 views. Number one shows beyond the swamp the Corona Dumps viewed east from about 111th Street and Fifty-second Avenue; number two is also looking eastward and shows Fifty-third Avenue in the foreground. This avenue, no longer designated as such, is now the entrance to the World's Fair Site; number Three is taken viewing east from 111th Street and Fifty-fifth Avenue and shows another portion of the dumps; number four is taken in the same direction, on the same street at Fifty-sixth Avenue and shows the dump being levelled. In the background (telegraph poles thereon) is 114th Street extending north and south. Just beyond it had been laid the Grand Central Parkway.

May 1923
Views 1,2, 3 and 4

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & [New York World's Fair of 1939-40.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Shown, in a set of three views, is the monumental George Washington by the sculptor James Earle Fraser, and a group of small figures called "The Moods of Time," by Paul Manship. The Washington statue stands at the west end of Constitution Mall, is sixty-five feet high and includes a fifteen-foot base. "The Moods of Time" depict morning, day, evening, and night. Seen from right to left they are: morning, night, day, and evening.

May 29, 1939
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

View 2 - Neg. # 1020

title: Queens: Colonial Avenue

folder: Horace Harding Boule & Colonial Avenue, Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park: (World's Fair Grounds). A set of 4 views showing what was once the Corona Dump for the City of New York. This putrid area has been converted into a place of beauty. Here, where once there were refuse heaps, will be held the greatest World's Fair of modern times. View number one is taken from 111th Street and Forty-sixth Avenue, looking eastward. The main exposition center will be at about where the train and steam shovel are seen in this view. View number two is taken looking northward from Horace Harding Boulevard at about Colonial Avenue, and shows an area that is now covered with the Grand Central Parkway, the Trylon and Perisphere, and the west side of the fair grounds. View number 3 and 4 are somewhat similar to view number two. In view 4 are seen hundreds of rust eaten hot water tanks doting the refuse heap.

October 1928.
Views 2&4: May 1923.
View 3: October 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
title: Queens: Horace Harding Boule - Colonial Avenue

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & [New York World's Fair grounds.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (World's Fair Site). A set of two views, showing the center of what will be eventually the largest park for the Borough of Queens. View No. 1 shows partially the Strongs Causeway Bridge over Flushing Creek, and a portion of Strongs Causeway. This bridge has been replaced with a larger one and the Causeway rebuilt and renamed the Horace Harding Blvd. View number two shows the Corona Dumps and also an old automobile dump. The area in these views has been graded and beautified and is now a part of the World's Fair Site.
1924
View 2:  June 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Viewing west (views 1,2) across the Flushing meadows toward the Corona dump hills, seen from Rodman Street and North Hempstead Turnpike. In the foreground is Mill Pond and the winding Flushing Creek. This area later became the main exposition center of the New York World's Fair 1939-40.
Views 2 and 3 are in a northwesterly direction across the marshy meadows from Rodman Street and show the Roosevelt Avenue subway "El" under construction in the background.

1925

folder: Roosevelt Avenue & St. George Road, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Roosevelt Avenue - St. George Road
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Viewing northeastward along the west bank of the Flushing River, the Whitestone spur of the Long Island Railroad and the marshes, from the Roosevelt Avenue bridge. Extensive improvements were later made in this area in connection with the New York World's Fair of 1939-40.

View 2 shows part of the same area being reconstructed into an automobile parking space for Fair visitors, the view being from the Willets Point Boulevard station of the I. R. T. and B. M. T. "El" on Roosevelt Avenue.

View 3 is eastward along the north side of Roosevelt Avenue toward the Willets Point Boulevard subway station and shows the station being enlarged (right) as the main north entrance to the Fair grounds. In the background is Flushing.

View 1: September 30, 1935
View 2: June 16, 1937
View 3: May 30, 1938

P. L. Sperr

folder: Grand Central Parkwa & 50th Avenue, Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): An extensive view, northeastward, across the swampy meadows from near Grand Central Parkway and 50th Avenue, showing the area that later became the main exposition center of the New York World's Fair 1939-40. On the horizon is the village of Flushing; on the left, the subway "El" on Roosevelt Avenue and the bridge that carries the avenue over the Flushing River.

View 2 shows another portion of the park, viewing north toward Northern Boulevard from about 38th Avenue. Note the dump hills on the left.

View 1: September 30, 1935
View 2: October 4, 1935

original_title: Queens: Roosevelt Avenue - Grand Central Parkway
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Worlds Fair Grounds) south of Roosevelt Avenue, at the left, elevated structure thereon) near the Grand Central Parkway. The area in the foreground is the site for the Army Camp. Beyond it is the ramp to the I.R.T. and B.M.T. station. View No. 2 is at a slightly different angle and shows at the right the I.R.T. storage yards. View No. 3 shows the background of views one and two, also shown is the Willets Point Blvd. station on Roosevelt Avenue at 126th Street.

May 30, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3

P.L. Sperr

folder: Grand Central Parkwa & Alpine Avenue, Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): The Administration Building of the World's Fair 1939-40, on the east side of Grand Central Parkway, below the Long Island Railroad tracks. To the left is the steel skeleton of the Trylon.

View 2 shows the United States Government Building fronting on the Court of Peace. The structure is in the modernized classical architecture and was designed by Howard L. Cheney. The two towers represent the legislative and judicial branches of the government and the figures represent Unity (right) and Peace.

View 1: July 3, 1938
View 2: May 29, 1939

P. L. Sperr

text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): The fifty-foot sundial, world's largest, by Paul Manship, at the World's Fair 1939-40. The sculpture depicts the three Fates passing Life's Thread back from Future to Present to Past under the Tree of Life. In view 2, viewing east across Washington Square, is the heroic figure of George Washington, with the United States Government Building in the background.

May 29, 1939
Views 1,2

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & New York World's Fair of 1939-40 & [Industrial exhibits; Communications Building; National Cash Register Company; United States Steel Corporation.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three of the industrial exhibits at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. View 1 shows the National Cash Register Company Building; view 2, the Communications Building, the architects of which are Francis Keally and Leonard Dean. A mural by Eugene Savage shows an Indian smoke signal and nude muses. Two 150-foot pylons adorn both sides of the entrance. View 3 is the United States Steel Corp. Building. It appropriately has its steel framework outside the shell of the structure. The architects are York and Sawyer.

View 1: June 21, 1940
View 2: May 29, 1939
View 3: June 16, 1940

P. L. Sperr

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & New York World's Fair of 1939-40 -[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics Pavilion.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): The pavilion of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russian) at the New York World's Fair 1939-40, seen across the Lagoon of Nations. Atop the tower of marble and porphyry at the entrance to the building is a stainless steel figure, designed by Vyacheslav Andreev, depicts the spirit of the Soviet worker. It weighs thirty tons and forms, after the Trylon--the World's Fair theme--the highest spot at the Fair. Architects of the pavilion are Boris M. Iofan and Karo S. Alabian. On the two wings of the building are reliefs of Stalin (left) and Lenin.

May 29, 1939
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & [New York World's Fair of 1939-40 & New York World's Fair Administration Building.], Queens, NY
text:
Completed Administration Building of the New York World's Fair 1939 which became ready today (Friday) for occupancy on Monday by a force of 600 employees who are being transferred from the Empire State Building over the weekend. Construction of the Administration Building, at the site in Flushing Meadow, Queens, was completed in the record time of 124 days. The cost was approximately $900,000.

"This picture is sent to you for publication only and must not be used for advertising or commercial purposes without written permission from New York World's Fair 1939 Incorporated."

folder: Flushing Meadow Park & New York World's Fair of 1939-40 & [Industrial exhibits.], Queens, NY
text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three of the industrial exhibits at the New York World's Fair 1939-40, situated in the southeast corner of the main exposition center. View 1 shows the Du Pont Building, "The Wonder World of Chemistry," the designer of which is Walter Dorwin Teague; view 2, the General Electric Company Building. Voorhees, Walker, Foley and Smith are the architects; view 3, the Petroleum Industry Building, the roof of which is painted blue and is illuminated at night with fluorescent tubes.

June 16, 1940
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three of the buildings of foreign governments at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. View 1 shows the Japanese Pavilion, modeled after an ancient shinto shrine, with its massive overhanging roof and is set in a setting of oriental gardens and rocky pools. View 2 shows the Czechoslovakian Building and view 3, Holland Village.

View 1: June 8, 1940
